CalebJamesDeLisl - (14:29): Scrypt implementation is finished! Now just debugging because it isn't producing the same output as the reference implementation.  
abusenius - (14:31): great  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (14:32): There was no salsa8 implementation, so I needed that. There was no PBKCS2-SHA256 implementation so I needed that too.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (14:35): The reference implementation encrypts files and is indeed written for the truly paranoid. It takes 200MB 5 seconds to hash a password. Fortunately the time/space parameters are configurable.

bblfish1 - (18:56): hello  
bblfish1 - (18:56): I have a number of interfaces with @ComponentRole annotations  
bblfish1 - (18:57): I would like to extract some of that code to reuse in other projects, but not have it depend on xwiki  
bblfish1 - (18:57): any ideas on how to do that, without just having two copies of the code?  
bblfish1 - (18:57): Or is this something one can do in Scala  
abusenius joined #xwiki at 19:01  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:04): bblfish1: Hi. I think you can just use the same code other places and the annotations will be ignored.  
bblfish1 - (19:04): well I still have to import the annotations  
lucaa - (19:04): bblfish1: one idea is to build the code independent and then wrap it with @componentRole interfaces for xwiki  
bblfish1 - (19:05): yes, that's where I was thinking Scala could perhaps come in really handy  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:05): I see. We have been working on cert creation re foafssl. http://svn.xwiki.org/svnroot/xwiki/contrib/sandbox/xwiki-crypto/src/main/java/org/xwiki/crypto/x509/  
bblfish1 - (19:05): but not sure if it is possible at all  
bblfish1 - (19:05): in Scala  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:06): I got signText to work as long as the user imports a CA cert when they sign up.  
lucaa - (19:07): ( bblfish1: I would  need to google for Scala a bit... )  
bblfish1 - (19:07): don't worry. I'll ask on #scala  
florinciu1 left at 19:09 (Quit: Leaving.  
bblfish1 - (19:12): nice CalebJamesDeLisl on X509  
bblfish1 - (19:12): what are you working on there?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:13): I wrote the x509 key maker. (it's derived from yours) I also wrote signText and pkcs12 storage for server side certs.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:14): I wrote another part for password based encryption. Right now I'm trying to implement a password based key derivation function.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:14): The only implementation is in C. fun fun fun.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:15): This KDF is really cool because you can tune how much cpu and how much memory it should take to hash a password.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:16): The default implementation uses like 200MB and 5 seconds to hash one password. It makes brute force not so attractive.  
bblfish1 - (19:16): ah ok. Do you really need to be that efficient? Are you preparing for 10 thousand people to sign up to xwiki a second ?  
bblfish1 - (19:16): oh!  
sburjan left at 19:16 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
lucaa left at 19:16 (Ping timeout: 264 seconds  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:17): I'm thinking maybe 1MB and 100ms is fine.  
bblfish1 - (19:17): 200MB for one password?  
bblfish1 is now known as bblfish ([[email protected]](https://dev.xwiki.org/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:17): Yup. Imagine trying to run a password guesser on that function.  
bblfish - (19:18): heh, but even better is not to have a password at all  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:18): I definitely agree.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:19): Of course RSA depends entirely on there being no efficient way to take a number to the 65537th root.  
bblfish - (19:20): you can change the exponent  
bblfish - (19:20): can be anything  
bblfish - (19:21): for some reason most implementations use that number  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:21): Oh. Snother thing is since I am doing PKCS#7 for signText compatibility, we have added to the interface encryptText so the user can encrypt text and send it as an email to the mail client with the private key.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:22): AKA send bank information (encrypted in database) to billing department.  
bblfish - (19:22): ah ok. But why not create a seperate framework for that? I mean why put it as part of the key generation piece  
bblfish - (19:23): then we can share code I mean…  
bblfish - (19:23): btw, we did an implementation of foaf+ssl for Clerezza in Scala last month  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:23): It is Seperate from the keymaker. It is in the X509 section which I'm thinking of renaming CMS since it's so PKCS7 oriented.  
fmancinelli joined #xwiki at 19:23  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:24): Hmm. I seem to be capitalizing all of my s's  
bblfish - (19:24): ah ok. Cool  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:24): The certs \_should\_ still be foafssl compatible.  
bblfish - (19:24): btw, one interesting thing about the clerezza code is that we placed the code inside the SSL library  
bblfish - (19:25): well it is very easy to make the certs foaf+ssl compatible :-)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:26): One goal in my mind is to allow permissions to be granted between wikis.  
bblfish - (19:26): well that is the whole point of foaf+ssl  
bblfish - (19:26): you should aim higher, permissions between any site  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:27): I think one of the limitations of foafssl will be that many site opperators don't want to interopperate, they want to be king of their kingdom.  
bblfish - (19:28): let us start working together. Then the network effect takes over  
bblfish - (19:28): at a certain size those who are outside loose out, and become insiders  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:29): I think the right approach is to make it easy to run a site on multiple computers in a "loose cluster" and make it easy for people just starting a site to have traffic by joining. Then there will be some users.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:30): \*by joining a group.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:31): I think the model to follow is fidonet. A bunch of small bbs's with no real content or user base could become a great network by joining forces.  
bblfish - (19:31): I am in Fontainbleau again, btw, so we could meet to let you know how you can do that with WebID  
bblfish - (19:31): the thing is to do that using web architecture  
bblfish - (19:31): anyway here is the scala code http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/clerezza/trunk/org.apache.clerezza.parent/org.apache.clerezza.platform.security.foafssl/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/clerezza/foafssl/ssl/X509TrustManagerWrapperService.scala  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:32): Mmm linq queries I like.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:33): "meet" I'm on the east coast of the USA :)  
bblfish - (19:33): ah ok  
bblfish - (19:33): forgot  
bblfish - (19:34): well, once someone auths into xwiki with foaf+ssl - you could use the above code- then you can crete groups of WebIDs  
bblfish - (19:34): very easy  
bblfish - (19:34): nd since they are global, two xwiki users  from different xwikis can access a resource  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:34): I think the real target audience is not the established sited but the newcomers who need to unite to get a foothold in the web.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:36): The big problem is trust. Who do you trust? do you trust who they trust? What happens when somebody starts spamming? Every decentralized network has the risk of becoming usenet.  
bblfish - (19:37): that is the next level of problem  
bblfish - (19:37): but you do it on a case by case basis  
bblfish - (19:37): it's completley open  
bblfish - (19:38): if you own a resource, you decide who to trust, or what rules for trust  
bblfish - (19:38): so if you have a blog, it can be friends of friends  
bblfish - (19:38): if you are a company: colleagues of colleagues  
bblfish - (19:38): whatever  
bblfish - (19:38): you work that out through relations in the linked data network  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:39): I really like also the possibility for a number of sites to unite for strength (think wikileaks) They have a group of sites which periodically mirror one another and that seems like a perfect use case.  
vmassol left at 19:45 (Quit: Leaving.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (19:52): Side note: Never ever rely on PKCS#12 password protection. It is far worse than it's predecessor PKCS#5.
